mn38:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn38:3.3: Now at that time a mendicant called Sāti, the fisherman’s son, had the following harmful misconception:
mn38:3.4: “As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
mn38:3.10: “Is it really true, Reverend Sāti, that you have such a harmful misconception:
mn38:3.11: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another’?”
mn38:3.12: “Absolutely, reverends. As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
mn38:3.13: Then, wishing to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the mendicants engaged, pressed, and kept talking with him:
mn38:3.14: “Don’t say that, Sāti! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
mn38:3.15: In many ways the Buddha has said that consciousness is dependently originated, since consciousness does not arise without a cause.”
mn38:3.16: But even though the mendicants pressed him in this way, Sāti obstinately held on to his misconception and insisted on stating it.

mn38:4.2: bowed, sat down to one side,

mn38:7.1: Consciousness is reckoned according the specific conditions dependent upon which it arises.
mn38:7.2: Consciousness that arises dependent on the eye and sights is reckoned as eye consciousness.
mn38:7.3: Consciousness that arises dependent on the ear and sounds is reckoned as ear consciousness.
mn38:7.4: Consciousness that arises dependent on the nose and smells is reckoned as nose consciousness.
mn38:7.5: Consciousness that arises dependent on the tongue and tastes is reckoned as tongue consciousness.
mn38:7.6: Consciousness that arises dependent on the body and touches is reckoned as body consciousness.
mn38:7.7: Consciousness that arises dependent on the mind and phenomena is reckoned as mind consciousness.
mn38:8.1: It’s like fire, which is reckoned according to the specific conditions dependent upon which it burns.
mn38:8.2: A fire that burns dependent on logs is reckoned as a log fire.
mn38:8.3: A fire that burns dependent on twigs is reckoned as a twig fire.
mn38:8.4: A fire that burns dependent on grass is reckoned as a grass fire.
mn38:8.5: A fire that burns dependent on cowdung is reckoned as a cowdung fire.
mn38:8.6: A fire that burns dependent on husks is reckoned as a husk fire.
mn38:8.7: A fire that burns dependent on rubbish is reckoned as a rubbish fire.
mn38:8.8: In the same way, consciousness is reckoned according the specific conditions dependent upon which it arises. …

mn38:94.1: Mendicants, when three things come together an embryo is conceived.
mn38:94.2: In a case where the mother and father come together, but the mother is not in the fertile part of her menstrual cycle, and the spirit being reborn is not present, the embryo is not conceived.
mn38:94.3: In a case where the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile part of her menstrual cycle, but the spirit being reborn is not present, the embryo is not conceived.
mn38:94.4: But when these three things come together—the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile part of her menstrual cycle, and the spirit being reborn is present—an embryo is conceived.
mn38:94.6: The mother nurtures the embryo in her womb for nine or ten months at great risk to her heavy burden.
mn38:94.7: When nine or ten months have passed, the mother gives birth at great risk to her heavy burden.
mn38:94.8: When the infant is born she nourishes it with her own blood.
mn38:94.9: For mother’s milk is regarded as blood in the training of the noble one.

mn38:97.1: But consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
mn38:97.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
mn38:97.3: He proclaims a Teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing.
mn38:97.4: He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life.
mn38:97.5: A householder hears that Dharma, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some respectable family.
mn38:97.6: They gain faith in the Realized One,
mn38:97.8: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
mn38:97.9: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
mn38:97.10: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness?’
mn38:97.11: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, put on the ochre robes, and go forth from the lay life into homelessness.
mn38:98.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing violence and harming. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all creatures.
mn38:99.1: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves pure by not thieving.
mn38:100.1: They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.
mn38:101.1: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.
mn38:102.2: They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other.
mn38:102.3: Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
mn38:103.2: They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, kind, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to many people.
mn38:104.1: They give up idle chatter. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
mn38:105.1: They avoid injuring plants and seeds. They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
mn38:105.2: They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows. They avoid beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, perfumes, and makeup. They avoid high and luxurious beds. They avoid receiving gold and money, raw grains, raw meat, women and girls, male and female slaves, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants, cows, horse, and mares, and fields and land. They avoid running errands and messages; buying and selling; falsifying weights, metals, or measures; bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
mn38:106.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and alms-food to look after the belly.
mn38:106.2: Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
mn38:106.3: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
mn38:106.4: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and alms-food to look after the belly.
mn38:106.5: Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
mn38:106.6: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

mn38:107.2: If the faculty of sight was left unrestrained, bad unwholesome qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

mn38:107.11: When they know a phenomenon with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
mn38:107.12: If the faculty of mind was left unrestrained, bad unwholesome qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
mn38:107.13: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
mn38:108.1: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
mn38:109.1: When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn38:109.3: After the meal, they return from alms-round, sit down in the meditation posture with their body erect, and establish mindfulness right there.
mn38:109.4: Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.
mn38:109.5: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all creatures, cleansing the mind of ill will.
mn38:109.6: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
mn38:109.7: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
mn38:109.8: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about wholesome qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
mn38:110.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn38:110.2: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …
